Important information

Here you can learn more about important indexes and what they mean regarding your health.

HRV

Heart Rate Variability (HRV) refers to the variation in time intervals between consecutive heartbeats. It's a measure of the beat-to-beat changes in heart rate and is influenced by the autonomic nervous system (ANS). Higher HRV indicates greater flexibility and adaptability of the ANS, while lower HRV is often associated with stress, fatigue, and various health conditions.

Stress Index

The Stress Index reflects stress levels and activity of the autonomic nervous system. Typical stress index can vary between the values of 5-15. High values of the stress index indicates low HRV and increased stress.

SNS Index

The Sympathetic Nervous System index typically refers to a measure of the activity level of the sympathetic nervous system, which is part of the autonomic nervous system responsible for the "fight or flight" response. It is known to increase heart rate, slow down your digestion and activate energy stores in your liver to an energy that can be used quickly.
During stress or high intensity exercise SNS index can be higher. Everything between -2 and +2 is normal.

PNS Index

The Parasympathetic Nervous System (rest-and-digest) is one of the branches of the autonomic nervous system, responsible for regulating many bodily functions, including heart rate, digestion, and respiratory rate.
Higher PNS index values generally indicate increased parasympathetic activity, while lower values may suggest decreased parasympathetic activity. During stress or during high intensity exercise much lower PNS index values can be expected.
Values between -2 and +2 is considered normal.
